name: ICNA Council for Social Justice
mission: To systematically facilitate assertive Muslim involvement in the field of human struggle for the rights of the poor and oppressed.
theoryOfChange: Shifting the narrative from solely providing aid to demanding systemic change through policy advocacy, anti-criminalization efforts, and supportive programming.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://icnacsj.org/zakat (Source: https://icnacsj.org/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Good donor alignment with manageable risk. Evidence quality is solid but still evolving in places.

judge_issues.message: BBB name 'Black Veterans For Social Justice' may not match 'ICNA Council for Social Justice' (similarity: 50%)
ZAKAT-ELIGIBLE claimed but no explicit zakat evidence found on website

score_details.score_summary: Icna Council for Social Justice shows strong impact and good alignment, with zakat compliance. Evidence score may reflect limited reporting capacity, not program weakness.

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://icnacsj.org/zakat (Source: https://icnacsj.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: The organization holds a Charity Navigator score of 86.5/100 and maintains a program expense ratio of 82.6% and fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised.
The charity is Zakat-eligible and follows specific policies for asnaf categories.
The organization reported total revenue of $834,440 and holds 7.3 months of working capital.
The organization offers various donation options and giving methods to support its advocacy work.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: With a Charity Navigator score of 86.5/100 and a high program expense ratio, the organization demonstrates strong financial health and efficient use of donor funds [1]. Its Zakat-eligible status and focus on social justice provide high alignment for Muslim donors [2].
areas_for_improvement: Enhancing data transparency to improve overall data confidence scores
Expanding third-party impact reporting to validate long-term advocacy outcomes

dimension_explanations.alignment: ICNA CSJ shows high alignment with Muslim donor values by integrating religious principles with social justice advocacy and maintaining a clear Zakat policy [2]. The organization provides multiple giving methods to facilitate community support for its mission of protecting the oppressed [4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization achieves a direct impact through its criminal justice and immigration programs, utilizing $834,440 in total revenue to fund these initiatives [3]. Its financial health is underscored by a program expense ratio of 82.6% and a fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised, indicating that the vast majority of resources are directed toward program services rather than overhead [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: The ICNA Council for Social Justice empowers the Muslim community to advocate for the rights of the poor and oppressed through systematic social and legal reform.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 82.6% ensuring funds reach core missions
Strong fundraising efficiency with only $0.09 spent per $1 raised
holds 7.3 months of working capital for operational stability
baseline_narrative.summary: The ICNA Council for Social Justice (CSJ) is a grassroots organization dedicated to facilitating assertive Muslim involvement in the struggle for human rights [1]. The organization focuses on critical social issues including criminal justice reform and immigration advocacy while maintaining Zakat-eligible status for its charitable activities [2].

all_citations.claim: rights of the poor and oppressed
all_citations.quote: To systematically facilitate assertive Muslim involvement in the field of human struggle for the rights of the poor and oppressed.
Our programs include Criminal Justice, Immigration, Hunger, Homelessness, and Islamophobia.
Your Zakat is used to support those in need through our social justice programs.
We distribute zakat to the poor and needy as defined by the Shariah.

Its Zakat-eligible status and focus on social justice provide high alignment for Muslim donors [2].

areas_for_improvement.context: While program spending is high, there is <cite id="13">no publicly available beneficiary data</cite> to calculate specific cost-per-outcome metrics.
The organization's impact is currently <cite id="14">unverified by external evaluations</cite>, which is common for emerging advocacy groups but limits high-rigor assessments.

bbb_assessment.summary: This organization has not yet been reviewed by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's high program ratio suggests that funds are reaching the field, even if specific outcome metrics are not yet published.
risk_factors: <cite id="13">Missing beneficiary counts for cost-effectiveness analysis</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary limitation is the <cite id="13">lack of granular impact data</cite> and external validation of advocacy success.

confidence.data_freshness: Data current as of 2023 Tax Year
confidence.notes: Strong financial data but limited outcome reporting.

alignment.explanation: Excellent fit for Muslim donors due to <cite id="6">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and focus on <cite id="7">underserved Muslim populations</cite> in the US.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust CSJ due to its <cite id="12">fully independent board of 8 members</cite> and a <cite id="15">86/100 accountability score</cite> from Charity Navigator.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="16">publish consistent beneficiary counts</cite> and seek third-party impact evaluations.

impact.explanation: Operations are highly efficient with an <cite id="5">83% to 82.6% program expense ratio</cite> and <cite id="9">resilient working capital</cite>.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="17">documenting a clear theory of change</cite> with explicit causal pathways for its advocacy work.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Developing evidence with strong financial tracking

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct implementation of advocacy and social programs

rich_narrative.headline: The ICNA Council for Social Justice empowers the Muslim community to advocate for the rights of the poor and oppressed through systematic social and legal reform.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support domestic social justice and civil rights advocacy within an Islamic framework while ensuring high financial efficiency.
donor_motivations: Want to fulfill zakat through US-based social justice initiatives
Care about systemic issues like criminal justice and immigration reform
Value lean organizations where nearly all funds go to programs
Support the empowerment of the American Muslim voice
giving_considerations: Advocacy impact is often long-term and harder to quantify than direct aid
The organization is in a growth phase with a high funding gap
Financial transparency is strong, but outcome reporting is still emerging
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking international humanitarian relief or those who require rigorous RCT-level evidence of impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects strong financial inputs and program activity but a lack of independent outcome verification.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: CSJ operates on the premise that combining direct legal/social support with public advocacy leads to systemic protection of Muslim civil rights.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that advocacy efforts are resulting in actual policy changes or improved lives for beneficiaries.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a <cite id="18">$834,440 revenue base</cite> and a significant funding gap, the org has high capacity to scale its advocacy programs.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="5">exceptionally high program expense ratio</cite> compared to larger advocacy peers.

similar_organizations.differentiator: More focus on direct social services/charity
similar_organizations.name: ICNA Relief

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="5">82.6% of its expenses toward programs</cite>, significantly exceeding industry benchmarks for lean operations.
CSJ demonstrates high efficiency in resource mobilization, spending only <cite id="10">$0.09 to raise every $1</cite> in charitable contributions.
The charity maintains <cite id="9">7.3 months of working capital</cite>, providing a strong buffer for long-term advocacy projects.

strengths_deep_dive: ICNA Council for Social Justice distinguishes itself through a dual-focus model that combines direct service with systemic advocacy. Their leadership is highly rated, earning a <cite id="11">perfect 100/100 Leadership & Adaptability score</cite> from Charity Navigator. This leadership oversees a diverse portfolio of initiatives, ranging from <cite id="2">Islamophobia monitoring to homelessness support</cite>. Furthermore, the organization maintains a <cite id="12">100% independent board</cite>, ensuring that governance is free from conflicts of interest and focused entirely on the mission of social equity.
rich_narrative.summary: The ICNA Council for Social Justice (CSJ) serves as a critical advocacy and social service arm for the American Muslim community, focusing on the <cite id="1">rights of the poor and oppressed</cite> through systematic reform. Operating primarily within the United States, the organization addresses a broad spectrum of social issues including <cite id="2">criminal justice, immigration, and hunger</cite>. Financially, the organization has demonstrated significant growth, reporting <cite id="3">$834,440 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 tax year, representing a <cite id="4">3-year revenue CAGR of 22.7%</cite>. This growth is paired with a high degree of fiscal efficiency, as the organization maintains a <cite id="5">program expense ratio of 82.6%</cite> according to recent filings, ensuring that the vast majority of donor funds are directed toward its core advocacy and service missions. The organization is <cite id="6">zakat-eligible</cite>, allowing Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations through programs that serve the <cite id="7">fuqara (poor) and masakin (needy)</cite> within the domestic context. With an <cite id="8">overall score of 86.86.5/100 from Charity Navigator</cite>, CSJ balances its advocacy work with strong organizational health, maintaining <cite id="9">7.3 months of working capital</cite> to ensure operational stability during economic fluctuations.
